Author: Gateway#3763
Content: [dscrd-hush] <dukeleto> @gigamesh not quite "backed up on BTC". The proof that they happened is backed up onto BTC. DPoW essentially tells BTC about transactions on another chain, to protect against 51% attacks.

Author: Gateway#3763
Content: [dscrd-hush] <dukeleto> Proof something happened is not the same as a backup of the actual data. Bitcoin is very strict about the data you put it, you can only put in a few bytes. So you put in proofs that things happened, not the actual things

Author: Gateway#3763
Content: [dscrd-hush] <dukeleto> "Proofs" are usually related to hash functions of things, because knowing the SHA256() of something is basically exactly the same as proving you knew the original thing. You will see security people sometimes publish a sha hash on Twitter, which is the hash of a statement. They are proving they said something publicly, at a certain time. People will be able to do something exactly like that with SilentDragon soon enough. And with Hush, you can put small amounts of data, or links to external sources for large datasets (bittorrent already exists, don't re-invent that wheel)

Author: Gateway#3763
Content: [dscrd-hush] <dukeleto> and to explain, later on, the security people will show the plaintext statement of the hash they published in  tweet. Sometimes related to embargoed CVEs and other fun stuff

Author: Gateway#3763
Content: [dscrd-hush] <AkiraX> i wonder if you could use the same type of math to prove God exists.

Author: Gateway#3763
Content: [dscrd-hush] <dukeleto> @gigamesh to explain about the WP, it's written in LaTeX, as Knuth intended, so it has a build system üòÉ

Author: Gateway#3763
Content: [dscrd-hush] <dukeleto> @gigamesh Hush was the first Zcash protocol coin to enable DPoW, it was a while ago, maybe over a year. We use that on top of the standard Equihash (200,9) (same as ZEC/ZEN/KMD), so we support all the same ASIC hw as those coins as well

Author: Gateway#3763
Content: [dscrd-hush] <dukeleto> I wrote the code for Hush+dpow over a year ago, I think it went into production many months later, so it depends how you measure

Author: Gateway#3763
Content: [dscrd-hush] <dukeleto> @siaynoq memos will always be 512 bytes in zcash protocol, and transactions can be up to 200KB in size, which means if we want to store a 4MB file, we use multiple transactions (and pay multiple transaction fees)

Author: Gateway#3763
Content: [dscrd-hush] <dukeleto> All komodo asset chains currently enforce a limit of 200KB for max xtn size and 4MB for max block size, Hush could decide to change that in the future, if we want, but those numbers are chosen very carefully
